title: Drawing, "Study for Staircase Decoration, Hanbury Hall, Worchestershire:  Achilles Revealing his Identity", ca. 1710
medium: Pen and brown ink, brush and wash on tan laid paper, lined
signed: Signed in pen and black ink, lower left hand corner of scene in lower register: J Th.
inscribed: Inscribed in graphite, bottom of scene in lower register: Palace of Lycomedes
provenance:
Augustin Daly [1]; 1900: acquired by Museum














[1] Sale, from American Art Galleries, New York, "Original pen-and-ink Drawing by Sir John Thornhill. Fresco Design," March 19-21, 1900.
creditline: Gift of Mrs. Charles B. Alexander
description: Drawing in two registers. Upper register: Octagonal shaped ceiling panel with a large group of figures of Greco-Roman gods. Flying figure of Mercury between the two registers. Lower register: within a painted architectural enframement a scene with many figures representing Achilles revealing his true identity at Court of Lycomedes. Frieze beneath scene depicting armor.

tombstone.epitaph: Drawing, "Study for Staircase Decoration, Hanbury Hall, Worchestershire:  Achilles Revealing his Identity", ca. 1710. Pen and brown ink, brush and wash on tan laid paper, lined. Gift of Mrs. Charles B. Alexander. 1900-1-1.
